metadata.description: Allocation of primary energy sources to end-use sectors, based on IEA World Energy Balances
metadata.methodology: Weighted average allocation derived from IEA energy flow data (2019-2024)
sources: IEA Energy Statistics Manual - Flow methodology
Brockway et al. 2019 - Strict Carnot exergy analysis
metadata.key_insight: Oil is 75% transport (high-exergy mechanical), gas is 50% low-temp heating (low-exergy 0.07 strict Carnot), renewables are ~95-100% electricity (high-exergy)

oil.notes: 75% road transport, aviation, shipping (mechanical work). 25% heating oil, refining losses, petrochemical feedstock (low-grade heat).

gas.notes: 40% used in combined-cycle power plants (high efficiency). 50% residential/commercial heating (low exergy). 10% industrial process heat. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

coal.notes: Primarily used for power generation and steel/cement production (high-temperature processes). 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

nuclear.notes: 100% baseload electricity generation. T&D losses already in efficiency factor. Exergy factor 1.0 to avoid double-counting.

hydro.notes: 100% electricity generation. T&D losses already in efficiency factor (0.87). Exergy factor 1.0 to avoid double-counting.

wind.notes: 100% electricity generation. T&D losses already included in efficiency factor (0.85). Exergy factor 1.0 to avoid double-counting.
wind.calculation: 1.00×1.0 = 1.00 (v2.8.1: removed T&D from exergy factor to avoid double-counting with efficiency factor)

solar.notes: 95% solar PV for electricity. T&D losses already included in efficiency factor (0.82). Exergy factor 1.0 for electricity to avoid double-counting.

biomass.notes: 70% traditional biomass (cooking, heating in developing countries - very low efficiency). 15% modern biofuels (transport). 10% biomass power. 5% industrial. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

geothermal.notes: 50/50 split between binary cycle power plants and direct-use heating applications. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

electricity_generation.description: All electricity has maximum exergy quality

low_temp_heating.description: Space heating, water heating, cooking (<100°C) - Strict Carnot minimum per Brockway et al. 2019: η = 1 - 273K/293K ≈ 0.07

calculation_example.description: How to calculate energy services from primary energy
steps: Step 1: Primary Energy (EJ) - from OWID data
Step 2: Useful Energy = Primary × Efficiency Factor (from efficiency_factors_corrected.json)
Step 3: Allocate to sectors using source_sector_allocation percentages
Or simplified: Energy Services = Useful Energy × Weighted_Exergy_Factor

example_coal.interpretation: Coal's useful energy of 32% reduces to 27.8% services due to 30% allocation to heat (low exergy)

example_wind.interpretation: Wind's useful energy equals services because 100% is electricity (maximum exergy)

allocation.low_temp_heating_50%: 0.225 EJ useful → 0.016 EJ services (exergy 0.07 strict Carnot)

example_gas.interpretation: Gas's useful energy of 45% reduces to 21.4% services because 50% goes to low-temp heating (strict Carnot exergy penalty)

validation_targets.global_2024_services: ~100-115 EJ (v2.8.1 with literature midpoint efficiency factors)
validation_targets.calculation: Global services = (Σ Useful Energy × Weighted Exergy) ≈ 605 EJ primary × 0.28 useful eff × 0.70 exergy ≈ 110 EJ
validation_targets.brockway_reference: Brockway et al. 2019 baseline ~100 EJ (2015) extrapolated to ~100-110 EJ (2024). v2.8.1 aligns with Brockway by using literature midpoint efficiency factors.
validation_targets.td_losses_note: T&D losses included in efficiency factors only (not double-counted in exergy factors). VRE efficiency factors include 3% storage/curtailment.
validation_targets.methodology_note: v2.8.1 uses literature midpoint efficiency factors and removes double T&D counting for renewables. Global exergy efficiency now ~18% (within literature range 10-18%).
